title: EM Scattering From a Target Above a 1-D Randomly Rough Sea Surface Using GPU-Based Parallel FDTD
abstract: This letter presents the graphics processing unit (GPU)-based finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) algorithm to investigate the electromagnetic (EM) scattering from a target above a rough sea surface. The proposed method is validated by comparing the numerical results to those obtained through sequential FDTD execution on a central processing unit (CPU), as well as through method of moments (MOM). The comparison results show a significant improvement in computation efficiency for GPU-based FDTD versus the message passing interface (MPI)-based FDTD. Furthermore, our parallel implementation is employed to study the influences of wind speed and the tilt angle of the target on composite scattering from the target above a sea surface.

motivations: There is a need for efficient computational methods to investigate electromagnetic scattering from targets above rough sea surfaces.
Existing methods, such as sequential FDTD execution on a CPU, are computationally intensive and require improvement.
objectives: Develop a GPU-based parallel FDTD algorithm to simulate EM scattering from a target above a rough sea surface.
Validate the proposed method by comparing its results with those obtained through sequential FDTD execution on a CPU and MOM.
methods: Implement a GPU-based FDTD algorithm to leverage parallel processing capabilities.
Compare the results of the proposed method with those obtained through sequential FDTD execution on a CPU and MOM to validate its accuracy.
results: Achieve significant improvement in computation efficiency for GPU-based FDTD compared to MPI-based FDTD.
Gain insights into the influences of wind speed and target tilt angle on composite scattering from the target above a sea surface.
